post_text: Mr. David Vinopal, Derry Area MS/HS STEM & Technology Education teacher, has been working cooperatively with the support of Derry Area School District Administration. Mr. Vinopal has been making 3D-printed masks with the District's 3D printers for the last two weeks from home! Each mask takes approximately 4.5 hours to produce. To date, Mr. Vinopal has made 65 masks that can be re-used. All that needs to be replaced is the square piece (filter) of the mask. These masks have been given to the Westmoreland Intermediate Unit as part of a community project. The WIU will apply elastic straps to the masks and weatherstripping to provide comfort around the edge. They will then distribute the masks to Westmoreland Emergency Management who will coordinate further distribution to local medical professionals.

post_text: Congratulations to Derry Area School High School student, Christian Burdick, who was a Finalist in the Shakespeare Monologue and Scene Contest. Honorable Mentions were given to Derry Area School District students Kelsey Geary, Ben Fetter, Matthew Harskowitch, Nate Cox, and Aspen Blystone. More than 1,000 area students from 110 schools competed in the preliminary rounds of the 26th Annual Shakespeare Monologue & Scene Contest at Pittsburgh Public Theater. Over ten days, contestants performed monologues and/or scenes they had chosen from the works of William Shakespeare. The Showcase of Finalists was held on Monday, February 17 at 7 pm. Grades 8-12 competed in the Upper Division and grades 4-7 competed in the Lower Division.

post_text: On January 27th, Grandview Elementary School was recognized as a Distinguished Title I School by the Pennsylvania Department of Education Division of Federal Programs at the Title I Improving Schools’ Performance Conference in Pittsburgh. The award recognizes schools that were in the Top 5% in Academic Achievement and Growth in the two most recently completed school years and schools that made the greatest gains in achievement in all student groups. This is the second consecutive year that Grandview has been designated a Title I Distinguished School. Grandview was presented the Keystone Award for Academic Excellence. Accepting the award were Rod Bisi, Principal; Kris Higgs, Director of Elementary Education; Alisa Gardner, Title I Teacher; Jen Faas, Title I Teacher; and Amy Casey Title I Teacher. (Photo)

post_text: Pictured are Mr. Richard P. Davis, representing the Pennsylvania Association of School Retirees, and Ms. Anna Maria DeFabo, Grandview Elementary Music Instructor. Mr. Davis presented Ms. DeFabo an award of $750 on behalf of the Westmoreland Chapter of PASR. The money will be used in the Grandview Elementary Music Department to purchase instruments and materials to implement a World Drumming program as well as help to begin to design and implement an ukelele program. These grants are provided on a round-robin basis to districts in Westmoreland County. The Westmoreland Chapter of PASR is made up of 300 retired school teachers who continue to give back to the communities they have served in the classroom. The national organization boasts over 30,000 members, all giving back to their communities. The organization also provides grants for student teachers and supports efforts and donations to shut-ins as well as to the Westmoreland County Food Bank for Packpack food programs for needy children.

post_text: On Mondays at the aft3r@dasd program at Grandview Elementary School, Mrs. Foster's "Lifting & Literacy" group meets after school. During this time, the students enjoy a mix of exercising and reading. The children have the opportunity to lift weights outside while listening to energizing music. They also get to release some energy with cardio activities. The group ends each Monday with continuing to read the book they are working on together. While in the fresh air, students practice oral reading fluency and comprehension. This group is full of fun, hard-working students that enjoy strengthening their muscles and reading skills!

post_text: As a part of Fire Prevention Week 21st CCLC Grandview Elementary School after school program K-5 students and families were introduced to Bradenville Fire Department firefighter Mr. Dale Hillis. Mr. Hillis spoke to the students about what to do if they smell smoke and how to call 911. They learned about the equipment the fire department uses to put out fires. Students learned what happens when you take a classic fairy tale like The Three Little Pigs and you join it with architectural inspiration from Frank Lloyd Wright? You get an awesome STEM picture book called The Three Little Pigs : An Architectural Tale written by Steve Guarnaccia. The moral of the story was to build an architecturally sound home in the event of a fire or any other natural disaster.

post_text: 21st CCLC D.A.M.S. middle school students traveled to the Loyalhanna Watershed, Nimick Family Center in Ligonier, PA to expand their understanding of the importance of water conservation and that “we all live downstream” in order to create an awareness of our environmental responsibilities. The students also learned about challenges in the Loyalhanna Creek Watershed including abandoned mine drainage, nutrient overloading, and sedimentation. Investigate permeable vs. impermeable surfaces and their impact on waterways. They were challenged to engineer a solution to one of these challenges and test it using a variety of materials on a working stream table.

post_text: Grandview Elementary 21st CCLC students and their families studied Aquatic Insets thanks to Community Partner, Ranger Jean Keene from Keystone State Park. The students learned that because aquatic insects look so different, they are sometimes forgotten that they are part of the animal kingdom. Aquatic insects are especially unique because they spend at least part of their lives in water. There are many different types of aquatic insects, and they have distinctive adaptations and features that allow them to thrive in this environment.

post_text: 21st CCLC learners at Derry Area Middle School spent a warm, fall afternoon splashing around in the Loyalhanna Stream with their 7th grade science teacher Mr. Zurinsky. Students learned the history of the Loyalhanna Watershed, the living and non-living components of a stream ecosystem, what macroinvertebrates are and how they are important indicators of water quality. The students had a blast investigating the health of a freshwater stream habitat by taking a look at what animals live under the water through hands-on collection and identification activities.

The students had a blast investigating the health of a freshwater stream habitat by taking a look at what animals live under the water through hands-on collection and identification activities.

post_text: Fourth and fifth grade Aft3r@DASD STEAM Team members, under the guidance of Mrs. Keller and Mrs. Maga, spent September preparing for a STEAM challenge sponsored by the Children's Museum of Pittsburgh. These students accepted Matt’s Makers Challenge to design and build a Rube Goldberg™ Machine that would pop a balloon in six or more steps and spent weeks perfecting their device through hard work and perseverance. Next week the STEAM Team is invited to the Children's Museum where contest winners will be announced and students will have the chance to explore a new exhibit: Rube Goldberg™, The World of Hilarious Invention Exhibit, before it opens to the public.

Derry Area School District's 21st CCLC 2018-19 after school learning program "aft3r@dasd" kicked off the 2018-19 school year by combining STEM and art to make STEAM.
Students at Grandview Elementary School used the Binary Coding system to design and create colorful Windchimes. As per 21st CCLC Program Director Debbie Gray, “We are very excited for this program this year, and look forward to offering a new and improved format.This year, we will have a lot of fun, hands on activities to build character, team work skills, and other important 21st century life skills that help our youth succeed inside and out of the classroom!”
Students in grades K-8 Grade are welcome to join in on the fun. Registration forms are located on the Derry Area School District website.

Wildflower ParTEA @ aft3r@dasd
Although wildflowers poke out and the pollinators buzz during the summer, 21st CCLC learners at Grandview Elementary School didn’t let that deter their curiosity in learning about Pennsylvania’s pollinators and wildflowers. The students sampled native wildflower tea while identifying and dissecting PA’s native flowers. Park Naturalist Jean Keene from Keystone State Park (DCNR) led the discussion in regard to the importance of native pollinators and their attraction with native flora.
Pictured are: (front) Maddie Pittman, Alaina Winter, Ashlyn Corbett, Danielle Marsh, Ava Crissey, Cael Brown. (Middle) Ian Butler, Nichole Ahlborn (parent). (back) Donovan Jones, Aaron Purcell, Jean Keene (DCNR)
